Museum of Vertebrate Zoology at UC Berkeley

abstract.para: The Macaulay Library is the world's largest and oldest scientific archive of biodiversity audio and video recordings. Our mission is to collect and preserve recordings of each species' behavior and natural history, to facilitate the ability of others to collect and preserve such recordings, and to actively promote the use of these recordings for diverse purposes spanning scientific research, education, conservation, and the arts.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: The Macaulay Library regularly undertakes recording expeditions to increase the breadth and depth of vocalizations and behaviors in the archive. In recent years we have targeted regions with a high diversity of species that are not yet well covered. See our Big Year Expeditions website (http://www.birds.cornell.edu/bigyear) detailing our efforts in 2007 to record North American birds in Alaska, Florida, Nova Scotia, and Texas. Between 2008-2010, expeditions visited the Canadian Arctic, Guatemala, South Carolina, Texas, western Mexico, the Great Basin and the Louisiana Gulf coast.

taxonomicCoverage.generalTaxonomicCoverage: The archive includes more than 175,000 audio recordings covering 75 percent of the world's bird species, with an ever increasing numbers of insect, fish, frog, and mammal recordings as well. The more recently established video archive includes over 50,000 clips, representing over 3,500 species.

address.deliveryPoint: Cornell Lab of Ornithology - 159 Sapsucker Woods Road

gbif.citation:
Cite the source of recordings as Macaulay Library (ML).

When possible, include the following data in your citation:

ML Media-collection Catalog-number
Common Name - Scientific name
Recordist
Location
Date
Macaulay Library/Cornell

For example:

ML Audio 2081
Green Heron - Butorides virescens
Sutherland, Charles A
United States, New York, Tompkins, 3 km NE of Ithaca, Sapsucker Woods Pond
29 July 1962
Macaulay Library, www.macaulaylibrary.org
Cornell Lab of Ornithology

To cite an online recording, use the URL from the specimen record page. This URL is a stable globally unique identifier, or GUID, and also approximates the format for a life science identifier(LSID):

institution_collection_catalog#
(e.g. macaulaylibrary.org/video/12345).

The long url form should not be used.
(e.g. macaulaylibrary.org/video/12345/cardinal-new-york-2011).

For more information: http://macaulaylibrary.org/cite-recordings
